title: Didn't work for a long time, but now it does!
comment: I used this app a loong time ago with the older versions of VLC, which worked flawlessly. But ever since VLC 2.0+? I couldn't get it to work and gave up. The app was able to detect my PC, but when I touched it to connect, it didn't do anything. If you have this problem, I have a solution that may or may not help you (doesn't hurt to try right?). This is one of many solutions found on the internet, but this one worked for me. I had to re-word the instructions, because some people suck at explaining things. Tested on Windows 7 64-bit & Nexus 5 (4.4.2, ART, Cataclysm, franco kernel).  1. In VLC, go to Tools->Preferences->Show settings: ALL. 2. Go to Interface->Main interfaces. 2. Under "Extra interace modules", enable "Web" by ticking the box. "http" should appear in the white box below, if not, type it in. 3. Go to Lua (under Main interfaces), under "Lua HTTP", create a password in the password box. 4. Go to Interface->Control Interfaces. Enable "Windows Service interface". "ntservice" should appear in the white box below, if not, type it in. 5. Save and restart VLC. 6. Redetect or close the app on your phone and restart the app. 7. Profit.

title: Genuinely Fantastic
comment: Out of all other VLC remotes, this has every feature that you would typically need. Granted, there are a few things I would like to see in it, but I was able to easily work around them. For one layout of it is nice, and it puts the options button properly in the top right corner rather than down on the bottom of the screen, which is what almost every other app of this variety does and it bothers the hell out of me. Makes for a very pleasant HTPC experience, using either a phone or tablet to control  the media playback whether it be videos or music. As a design freak, I can see room for improvement in the layout, placement and sizing of the UI, but as it is it's still highly functional which is the most important part. Also as a small note, you can only browse the main drive on your computer (i.e. C:\\ drive on PCs) which is slightly problematic for I use a file server to hold my massive library of movies, though was able to bypass this problem with symbolic links. If possible, I would also like to request that if a server isn't found on one of the remembered IPs, it should check the other ones, in cases of dynamic IPs. Again though, job well done good sir.

title: Works perfectl on MAC  OS X (check developer page)
comment: (If it does not work anymore after an update of VLC than obviously the HOST file is changed, this has nothing to do with the developer as he has no control on what VLC updates!)   VLC 2.x.x @ MAC OS X Works Perfectly on MAC OS X with VLC 2.x.x  Step 1: VLC on MAC: Navigate to: Preferences -> Show All -> Interfaces -> Main interfaces and write 'http' into the field Extra interface modules  Step 2: open terminal and type the following: sudo bash -c 'echo 0.0.0.0/0 > /Applications/VLC.app/Contents/MacOS/share/lua/http/.hosts'    Step 3. Close VLC on MAC and reopen it for changes to take affect  Step 4. Run the VLC remote app on Android and it should be detected there now  PS: this will work directly if no firewalls are interfering in between
